messages.messageBody:
We will have them for sale Tuesday also. Bob Elder 1 (800) 407 1592. Thanks!

Tom Helm <junkmail@...> wrote: I am sure you all got this in your mailbox but if not...
-t

Begin forwarded message:

> From: "Namikawa Heibei Co., Ltd." <info@...>
> Date: March 2, 2006 9:55:18 PM PST
> To: "Namikawa Heibei Co., Ltd." <info@...>
> Subject: New Arrival !! From Namikawa
>
> A new book on Japanese sword polishing has arrived.
>
> We have updated our web site, so you may order
>
> directly through our online shopping.
>
>
>
> http://www.namikawa-ltd.co.jp/cgi-bin/item_e.cgi?cate=13&no=5
>
>
>
ï¿¼
>
>
>
> The Art of Japanese Sword Polishing
> Setsuo Takaiwa
> Yoshindo Yoshihara
> Leon and Hiroko Kapp
>
> Hardcover 192 pages
> 190 x 260mm 910g
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
> The following is the shipping cost for 1 copy of this book sent by
> EMS airmail.
>
> Asia 1800 yen
>
> North and Central America 2400 yen
>
> Oceania 2400 yen
>
> Middle East 2400 yen
>
> Europe 2800 yen
>
> Russia 2800 yen
>
> South America 3800 yen
>
> Africa 3800 yen
>
>
>
> We do have this book in stock, but according to the volume of sale,
>
> we might have to have you wait.
>
> But we will be able to ship it out in about 2 weeks.
>
>
>
> Thank you very much.
>
>
>
> Best regards,
>
> Namikawa
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
> [ About the Book ]
> Japanese swords have long been prized for their aesthetic beauty as
> well as their functional properties. As polishing plays a vital
> role in determining the sword's final shape and appearance, an
> understanding of the polisher's art is essential for anyone
> interested in this unique weapon.
> âFROM CHAPTER ONE
>
>
> To understand Japanese sword polishing is to understand the
> Japanese sword. Down through the years, the great sword
> connoisseurs in Japan have been sword polishers. A swordsmith can
> spend a large amount of time forging a classic sword, but refining
> and bringing out its final shape, color, and texture so that all
> the details of the steel and hamon (the temper line) are clearly
> visible is the responsibility of another craftsman
> âthe sword polisher.
>
> The Art of Japanese Sword Polishing is the first book in English to
> examine in great detail the polisher's techniques, for which they
> may apprentice for as long as ten years. It illustrates the
> methods, materials, and tools used for this process. But the book's
> true aim is to bring to readers an appreciation of the beauty of a
> well-crafted Japanese sword. As readers learn both how the sword
> polisher enhances the beauty of a blade and how he handles the
> problems of coaxing out its finest qualities through his polishing
> techniques, they will come to a higher understanding of the fine
> art of making a Japanese sword, and be able to view, purchase, or
> collect swords with greater pleasure.
>
>
>
>
>



[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
